articles.headline: Hot Tech Start-Ups May Face a Long and Bumpy Fall
articles.snippet: The worldwide market gyrations will filter down to Silicon Valley, with start-ups that need cash likely to be the first to undergo tougher scrutiny.
articles.abstract: The worldwide market gyrations will filter down to Silicon Valley, with start-ups that need cash likely to be the first to undergo tougher scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As stock markets have tumbled, public company shareholders were not the only ones wondering what would become of their portfolios. Venture capitalists also began fretting about whether the plunge — which resulted last week in the worst week for American stocks since 2011 and a renewed sell-off on Monday — would cool the heady market for shares of private companies, especially in Silicon Valley.

articles.headline: Migrants Race North as Hungary Builds a Border Fence
articles.snippet: On a chaotic path through the Balkans, tens of thousands of migrants are pushing to reach northern Serbia before Hungary seals the border.
articles.abstract: On a chaotic path through the Balkans, tens of thousands of migrants are pushing to reach northern Serbia before Hungary seals the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: TISZASZIGET, Hungary — Roiling everything in its path, a wave of tens of thousands of migrants and refugees — many fleeing wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan — has worked its way up the length of the Balkans in recent days.

articles.headline: Jet Lag ‘Cures’ Aplenty, but None That Work for All
articles.snippet: Although science is closer to understanding the basic mechanisms that make many travelers feel so awful when crossing time zones, there is no one-size-fits-all cure.
articles.abstract: Although science is closer to understanding the basic mechanisms that make many travelers feel so awful when crossing time zones, there is no one-size-fits-all cure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rita Gunther McGrath, a Columbia Business School professor, is one of those business travelers who do not care about delays, cancellations or navigating a new location. What does concern her is the seeming inability to conquer jet lag, and the accompanying symptoms that leave her groggy, unfocused and feeling, she says, “like a dishrag.”

articles.headline: John Kasich Balances His Blue-Collar Roots and Ties to Wall Street
articles.snippet: A chapter in Mr. Kasich’s life story conflicts with the narrative about his working-class past: the nearly eight years he spent as an investment banker with Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: A chapter in Mr. Kasich’s life story conflicts with the narrative about his working-class past: the nearly eight years he spent as an investment banker with Lehman Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — As the people of Ohio already know — and Republican voters elsewhere are just beginning to find out — Gov. John R. Kasich grew up in working-class McKees Rocks, Pa., the son of a postal worker and the grandson of a coal miner. His grandfather was so poor, Mr. Kasich recently told voters in New Hampshire, that he would bring home scraps of his lunch to share with his children.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Netflix to Add Films and TV Series for Teenagers
articles.snippet: The streaming service will introduce exclusive films and television series as part of a strategy to position itself as a digital entertainment hub for the postmillennial generation.
articles.abstract: The streaming service will introduce exclusive films and television series as part of a strategy to position itself as a digital entertainment hub for the postmillennial generation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Netflix is entering the awkward teenage years, at least with its latest programming push.

articles.headline: From Venezuela to Iraq to Russia, Oil Price Drops Raise Fears of Unrest
articles.snippet: The downward spiral of oil prices and the reluctance to reduce production are threatening to destabilize economies and governments in many places that are already fragile.
articles.abstract: The downward spiral of oil prices and the reluctance to reduce production are threatening to destabilize economies and governments in many places that are already fragile.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil, the lifeblood of many countries that produce and sell it, appears to be rapidly turning into an ever-cheaper economic curse.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: A Warning on China Seems Prescient
articles.snippet: Kenneth Rogoff, a Harvard professor, has made a career of studying financial crises, and he has long warned of one coming to China.
articles.abstract: Kenneth Rogoff, a Harvard professor, has made a career of studying financial crises, and he has long warned of one coming to China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth Rogoff has long warned of a potential financial crisis in China.

articles.headline: Advisers Work to Calm Fearful Investors
articles.snippet: On some days, market psychology can count for more than long-term fundamentals, pushing panicked investors to sell.
articles.abstract: On some days, market psychology can count for more than long-term fundamentals, pushing panicked investors to sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even a pep talk from the chief executive of Apple, the single biggest American company by market value, did little to soothe investors on Monday.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Puerto Ricans Seeking New Lives Put Stamp on Central Florida
articles.snippet: A population change is transforming the Orlando region economically, culturally and politically.
articles.abstract: A population change is transforming the Orlando region economically, culturally and politically.
articles.lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — When Manuel Hernandez, a teacher in Puerto Rico, looked at the reasons to stay home or to take a chance on joining the ever-growing Puerto Rican diaspora in Central Florida, it was not a hard call.

articles.headline: A Stock Market Rout in a Month That Hedge Funds Would Sooner Forget
articles.snippet: The sudden and rapid sell-off across global markets has caught many on Wall Street off guard.
articles.abstract: The sudden and rapid sell-off across global markets has caught many on Wall Street off guard.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his getaway cabin deep in the woods, an experienced adviser to wealthy hedge fund investors was hopping from one conference call to another to manage clients’ mounting anxiety.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Stocks Deepen Their Slide After Early Gains Evaporate
articles.snippet: A strong rally on Wall Street faded rapidly on Tuesday afternoon, killing hopes for an end to the recent turmoil in the markets.
articles.abstract: A strong rally on Wall Street faded rapidly on Tuesday afternoon, killing hopes for an end to the recent turmoil in the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: A sudden reversal in United States stock prices late in trading on Tuesday produced a sixth consecutive session of losses and heightened uncertainty about the challenges facing global markets.

articles.headline: In Syria, Potential Ally’s Islamist Ties Challenge U.S.
articles.snippet: Ahrar al-Sham opposes the Syrian president and the Islamic State and seems like a logical Western ally, but its links to Al Qaeda trouble American policy makers.
articles.abstract: Ahrar al-Sham opposes the Syrian president and the Islamic State and seems like a logical Western ally, but its links to Al Qaeda trouble American policy makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — A rebel group with thousands of fighters, political clout and close ties to key regional powers has emerged as one of the most powerful opposition forces in Syria in recent months. It has vowed to fight the Islamic State and called for engagement with the West.

articles.headline: Bets That the Fed Will Delay Interest Rate Rise Could Be Premature
articles.snippet: As stocks slumped, sentiment grew among investors that the central bank, which takes a broad view of the economy, would hold off on raising rates this year.
articles.abstract: As stocks slumped, sentiment grew among investors that the central bank, which takes a broad view of the economy, would hold off on raising rates this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As markets quake and stock prices fall, investors increasingly are betting that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates this year.

articles.headline: China’s Party-Run Media Is Silent on Market Mayhem
articles.snippet: News organizations tied to the Communist Party have had to tread carefully in reporting on the crumpling stock market.
articles.abstract: News organizations tied to the Communist Party have had to tread carefully in reporting on the crumpling stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After China’s stock markets crumpled, prompting a global sell-off, People’s Daily, the premier newspaper of the Chinese Communist Party, had other things on its mind.
